intro: Amsinckia lycopsoides var. bracteosa, commonly known as the bracteate desert parsley, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and clusters of small, blue to purple flowers. The plant has heart-shaped, lobed leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or rocky soils. Its unique morphology and adaptations make it well-suited for survival in harsh desert conditions.
